G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as this is a civil action for money damages well within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as this is a civil action for money damages well within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a71, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§1, 2, and 8 because the Property that is the subject of this action is located in Somerville, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court, and the events and omissions giving rise to Plaintiff’s claims occurred in Somerville.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: G.L. c. 186, §14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a76B.proposition: An award of damages pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14 in an amount not less than three (3) months’ rent, i.e., $4,500, or Plaintiff’s actual and consequential damages, whichever is greater, but in any event not less than $2,000, plus interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, §6B;

G.L. c. 261, \u00a71 et seq..proposition: Costs of this action, including filing fees and other allowable costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 261, §1 et seq.;

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, §14 is not limited to physical entries onto the premises but extends to substantial interferences with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises that are the “natural and probable consequence” of the landlord’s acts or omissions.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court expressly rejects any requirement of landlord intent and holds that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment exists where the substantial interference is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, even though there was no physical entry. It applies that principle to non-physical interference (noise from a bar operated under a lease the landlord controlled) and denies the landlord rent because the premises were not reasonably habitable, aligning with the scope of liability described in the proposition and matching the statutory quiet enjoyment concept under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in all residential leases and cannot be waived by the tenant.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that “every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy,” which supports the first part of the proposition—that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in all leases, including residential. However, the opinion does not address, even implicitly, whether that covenant “cannot be waived by the tenant.” There is no discussion of waivers, exculpatory clauses, or the enforceability of any purported waiver, so the case does not support the non‑waivability component of the proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.” 385 Mass. at 101-102.

*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that render the premises unfit for the purposes for which they were rented, or that prevent the tenant from using the premises in a customary, reasonable manner.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard of fault (at least negligence and notice) necessary to establish a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, especially in the context of lead paint violations. However, in the quoted portion it does not articulate the substantive scope of the covenant in terms of protecting tenants from serious interferences or conditions rendering premises unfit or unusable in a customary, reasonable manner; those descriptions come from earlier cases like Simon v. Solomon and Cruz, which are only referenced. Thus this case is not the source for the specific proposition stated, even though it is generally consistent with it.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interferences with the tenancy, including conditions that render the premises unfit for the purposes for which they were rented, or that prevent the tenant from using the premises in a customary, reasonable manner.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season “seriously impairs the character and value of the leased premises” and “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment,” thus recognizing that serious conditions affecting habitability fall within that covenant. While the court does not expressly use the “unfit for the purposes” or “customary, reasonable manner” phrasing, its reasoning that lack of heat during the heating season is a compensable breach of quiet enjoyment is consistent with the proposition that the covenant protects against serious interferences with the tenancy rendering the premises unfit for their intended residential use.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 368 Mass. 5.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in all residential leases and cannot be waived by the tenant.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 368 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The provided portion of Hemingway v. Commonwealth deals exclusively with the constitutionality of the Massachusetts ‘idle and disorderly persons’ statute and First Amendment overbreadth/vagueness, not landlord-tenant law. It does not mention leases, quiet enjoyment, or waiver by tenants. Therefore, this case cannot be cited as authority for an implied, non-waivable covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 368 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: We take this opportunity to observe that, despite our finding that the § 53 offense of being an idle and disorderly person is not void for vagueness, other parts of the statute are constitutionally suspect. The statute is archaic. In its laconic provisions it covers a multitude of crimes, some of which are completely alien to modern times, others of which may in the future be subject to the type of challenges raised here.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: With such notice, Defendant was required to take reasonable steps in good faith to address and abate the disturbance. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 717–19 (landlord liable for noise from lounge operated on premises where interference was natural and probable consequence of landlord’s arrangements and failure to control); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994) (landlord may be liable for failure to exercise control to prevent foreseeable harm and disturbance where it retains the ability to do so).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landlord who has notice of serious disturbances caused by third parties, and who retains the ability to take measures to remove or control those persons, may be liable under the covenant of quiet enjoyment if it fails to take such measures. The court frames the issue in terms of whether the interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do, and remands for fact-finding on what steps the landlord took, making clear that inaction in the face of foreseeable harm and retained control can result in liability. This aligns with the proposition that, upon notice, a landlord must in good faith take reasonable steps within its control to address and abate the disturbance.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The issue on which our decision turns, then, is whether this serious interference with the tenancy of the plaintiffs is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. … We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Similarly, where a landlord has notice of serious misconduct or disturbance by one tenant that substantially interferes with another tenant’s use of her apartment and fails to take reasonable steps within his power to address it, the landlord’s omission can constitute an “indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses implied warranty of habitability, code-based obligations, and constructive eviction in general, but it does not address landlord responsibility for one tenant’s misconduct disturbing another tenant, nor does it interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14’s ‘indirect interference’ language. The cited pages contain no discussion of inter-tenant disturbances or a landlord’s duty to take reasonable steps to stop them. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about indirect interference with quiet enjoyment based on failure to respond to a disturbing tenant.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Admittedly the rule suggested above does not cover the situation constituting a ‘constructive eviction’ of a tenant which is discussed in the court’s opinion, but that is because the facts of the present cases do not involve such a situation. There is nothing to suggest that our courts which have heretofore given relief to a tenant who is the victim of a ‘constructive eviction’ will not continue to do so in an appropriate case.”

*Sampier v. Zaretsky*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This level of interference rises to the level of a substantial and serious impairment of tenancy required to establish a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14.
*Sampier v. Zaretsky*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion is a domestic relations case about survival/merger of a separation agreement and the standard for modifying child support, not a landlord‑tenant case. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14, quiet enjoyment, or what constitutes a substantial and serious impairment of tenancy. The proposition about interference with tenancy and breach of quiet enjoyment is therefore unrelated to the issues decided in Sampier v. Zaretsky, and the case cannot support that proposition.
*Sampier v. Zaretsky*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “We are concerned here only with the provisions of a separation agreement with respect to the support of children. ‘An agreement to fix a spouse’s support obligation for minor children stands on a different footing. Parents may not bargain away the rights of their children to support from either one of them.’… But a Probate Court support order may recast the burden of support for a child, as expressed in a separation agreement…” (24 Mass. App. Ct. at 236–37).

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Accordingly, under G.L. c. 186, §14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover at least three months’ rent ($4,500) as statutory damages, plus costs of the action and such other relief as is just.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to impose liability for interference with quiet enjoyment and specifies that the remedy is either actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. That directly supports the proposition that, upon a § 14 violation, a plaintiff is entitled at least to three months’ rent as statutory damages, along with costs and other appropriate relief. The case does not state the $4,500 amount, but it clearly supports the legal measure of minimum statutory damages and costs under § 14.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”
...
On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.

*Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Ma.raw_text: *Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Mass., Inc.*, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 443, 446–47 (1999)
*Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Ma.proposition: To the extent the Court deems it appropriate and within its discretion, Plaintiff also seeks equitable or declaratory relief recognizing the breach and protecting her right to quiet enjoyment going forward. See generally *Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Mass., Inc.*, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 443, 446–47 (1999) (declaratory and equitable relief within court’s authority where appropriate to resolve disputes involving ongoing rights).
*Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Ma.case_name: Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Massachusetts, Inc.
*Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about whether the insurer violated G.L. c. 93A and related duties of good faith; it does not discuss declaratory judgments, equitable relief, or the court’s discretionary authority to issue such relief to resolve ongoing rights. The only remedy addressed is damages and attorney’s fees under c. 93A on remand. Thus, citing this case for the general availability of equitable or declaratory relief is inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
*Green v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The order of the Appellate Division dismissing the appeal is vacated. A new judgment shall enter for the plaintiff on her claim pursuant to G. L. c. 93A. The case is remanded to the District Court for further proceedings on the issue of damages and attorney’s fees pursuant to G. L. c. 93A, § 9. The judge may reopen evidence for this purpose or may act on the existing record."
